To change the SYS user's password, you can use the ALTER USER statement, the PASSWORD command, or the ORAPWD command line utility. The method you choose will depend on how your database is configured, specifically on how the REMOTE_LOGIN_PASSWORDFILE initialization parameter is set. If the REMOTE_LOGIN_PASSWORDFILE is set to SHARED or null, you must use ORAPWD to change the SYS password. If it is set to EXCLUSIVE, you can use the ALTER USER statement. The ALTER USER statement has advantages in Oracle Data Guard environments and allows for changing the password within the Oracle database instance.

To create a user-schema mapping for a database, follow these steps:

1. Log in to Enterprise Manager Cloud Control as an administrative user.
2. Navigate to your database by selecting Databases from the Targets menu.
3. Click on the database name in the list displayed to access the database page.
4. Under the Administration menu, choose Security, then Enterprise User Security. This will lead you to the Oracle Internet Directory Login page.
5. Enter the distinguished name (DN) of a directory user who can administer enterprise users in the User field. Input the user password in the Password field and click Login.
6. Once logged in, click on Configure Databases. This action will display a list of databases registered in the identity management realm.
7. Select the specific database you want to work on, then click on Configure.
8. On the Configure Database page, click on the User-Schema Mappings tab. Here, you will see all the user-schema maps created at the database level.
9. To create a new user-schema mapping, click on Create. This will take you to the Create Mapping page.
10. Under the From section, you can select Users to map an individual enterprise user to a database schema, or alternatively, choose Subtree to map a directory subtree.

By following these steps, you can successfully create user-schema mappings for a database.
